descriptions.content:
This auxiliary implies that the speaker regards his or her assertion as a probability, not a certainty.

The auxiliaries ཡིན་འགྲོ་, ཡོད་འགྲོ་, are based on the verbs ཡིན་ and ཡོད་, which correspond respectively to essential and existential formulations. They are used either as copulas (linking verbs) or as auxiliaries and occur in the same position as ཡིན་ and ཡོད་.

They may be translated in English by the adverb “probably.” Their negative counterparts མེད་འགྲོ་, མིན་འགྲོ་,[1] express a similar meaning with a slightly weaker probability,[2] but they occur more frequently than the positive auxiliaries.

  • ཉལ་ཁང་མན་འགྲོ (མིན་འགྲོ) “That’s maybe the bedroom.”
  • ཉ་ཁང་ཡིན་འགྲོ “That’s probably the bedroom. It must be the bedroom.”
  • ལུག་ཤ་ཉོ་ས་ཡོད་འགྲོ “There’s probably a place to buy mutton.”
  • གསོལ་མར་ཉུང་དྲག་པ་མེད་འགྲོ “Maybe there isn’t enough butter.”
  • ཁོང་ཇ་ཁང་ལ་ཕེབས་པ་མིན་འགྲོ “He may have gone to the teashop.”
  • ཕྱག་དཔེ་འདི་རྒན་ལགས་ལ་མེད་འགྲོ “The teacher may have this book (pecha)”

Note: The negative forms མེད་འགྲོ་ and མིན་འགྲོ་ are usually used in a positive sense, as the above examples indicate. However, exceptionally, with a falling intonation, they may also express a negative judgment corresponding to “probably not,” in which case they are similar to མེད་པ་འདྲ་ and མིན་པ་འདྲ་.

  • ཕྱག་དཔེ་འདི་རྒན་ལགས་ལ་མེད་འགྲོ “The teacher probably doesn’t have this book (pecha).”

 

[1] Pronounced with a rising intonation.

[2] In English these correspond more to “maybe” than to “probably,” but the meaning also depends on the intonation.
